template.name: AWS_Guidance for Agentic AI Operational Foundations
template.desc: This Guidance demonstrates how to accelerate and de-risk AI agent development through a comprehensive, production-ready solutions approach. It shows organizations how to establish essential service capabilities including multi-model governance, robust observability, and automated guardrails - critical elements that are often overlooked in early AI projects. The solution helps teams avoid common pitfalls and reduce time-to-value by providing pre-integrated components and proven architectural patterns that support the complete AI application lifecycle. By implementing centralized monitoring, evaluation, and safety controls, this guidance enables organizations to scale their AI initiatives reliably while maintaining visibility and control over model behavior and costs. The offerings approach transforms scattered proof-of-concepts into sustainable, production-grade AI solutions that can evolve with business needs.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1030 - Network Segmentation||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

AU-6 Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

reference.name: Getting started with the AWS API

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1030 - Network Segmentation||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

  • A new type of long-lived key on AWS: Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

  • AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy reference

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1016 - Vulnerability Scanning||ATLAS - AML.M0016 - Vulnerability Scanning

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance||ATLAS - AML.M0015 - Adversarial Input Detection

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

  • AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy reference

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance||ATLAS - AML.M0015 - Adversarial Input Detection

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1030 - Network Segmentation||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.desc:

countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-131
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-131: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size The product does not correctly calculate the size to be used when allocating a buffer, which could lead to a buffer overflow.

weakness.name: CWE-284

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-610
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-610: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

countermeasure.name: Apply provenance and source attribution
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Record lineage and source attribution for each memory update:
    • Integrate metadata tracking into the Agent Memory Store to capture details about the origin of each memory entry. This includes details such as the time of update, the identity of the actor (human, system, or AI tool) responsible for the update, and the source dataset or interaction.
    • Ensure any updates to memory also document any transformations or derived data processes that contribute to the update.
    • Use a standardized metadata format for lineage and source attribution to ensure interoperability and easy integration with forensic tools.
  2. Maintain immutable signed audit logs:
    • Implement a logging mechanism that uses cryptographic signatures to ensure immutability. Each log entry should be signed using private keys to prevent tampering.
    • Store logs in a tamper-proof ledger or a blockchain-based system to guarantee integrity and immutability.
    • Include contextual information in each log entry, such as the timestamp, associated memory updates, and any lineage metadata, to provide a comprehensive audit trail.
    • Establish clear access control policies for the audit logs, allowing only designated individuals or systems to access and verify them.
  3. Track knowledge lineage for forensic rollback:
    • Implement a version control mechanism in the Agent Memory Store to keep track of all previous states of memory records. This enables forensic rollback in case of memory corruption or unauthorized edits.
    • Ensure every rollback action is logged within the signed audit logs to maintain accountability and transparency.
    • Design lineage tracking to include a branching mechanism, which allows for the reconstruction of a memory's entire historical trajectory along with the sources contributing to each intermediate state.
    • Develop a user interface or API to facilitate forensic rollback and allow for auditing of memory changes at granular levels.

References

  • Record Lineage and Source Attribution in Intelligent Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1047 - Audit||ATLAS - AML.M0014 - Verify AI Artifacts

countermeasure.name: Configure retention and user oversight
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Apply TTL-based purging: Set up a Time-To-Live (TTL) mechanism to automatically purge memory entries after a predefined time period:
    • Analyze the sensitivity of the data stored in memory and define an appropriate TTL period (e.g., hours, days, weeks).
    • Leverage built-in TTL functionality in database systems or memory stores that support expiration policies (e.g., Redis).
    • Configure TTL settings during memory entry creation to ensure automated purging after the specified duration.
    • Implement scheduled audits to confirm that expired memory entries are successfully deleted.
  2. Encrypt memory at rest and in transit: Ensure robust encryption to protect stored and transmitted memory:
    • Utilize a secure encryption algorithm (e.g., AES-256) to encrypt memory data at rest.
    • Integrate encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher) for data transit between the memory store and its consumers.
    • Regularly rotate encryption keys using an enterprise-grade key management solution to minimize exposure to compromised keys.
    • Perform vulnerability scans and penetration testing to verify the adequacy of encryption mechanisms.
    • Define fallback procedures to mitigate incidents, such as memory decryption failures or key compromise.
  3. Provide mechanisms for users to review, correct, and delete memory entries: Introduce controls that allow users to manage stored data effectively:
    • Develop a user interface or API endpoint that enables authenticated users to view memory records associated with their identities.
    • Allow users to submit corrections via guided forms or dynamic editing options, ensuring updates follow proper validation and integrity checks.
    • Offer secure deletion functionality for users to remove unwanted or incorrect data from memory.
    • Log all review, correction, and deletion activities for audit purposes while safeguarding user privacy.
    • Educate users on data management practices, emphasizing the importance of accurate memory entries and secure deletion.

Adopting these countermeasures will mitigate risks associated with data compromise, inaccuracies, and unauthorized retention within an Agent Memory Store.

References

  • Memory Risk Framework and Mitigation Playbook for Production-Ready AI Agents

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1029 - Remote Data Storage||ATLAS - AML.M0012 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Define trust boundaries and permissions
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Define memory trust boundaries: Clearly segment the memory store into distinct zones based on data classification and sensitivity. Each zone should represent a separate trust boundary. For example, segregate memory designated for unverified information from memory used for mission-critical or verified data. Use these boundaries to track and enforce security policies consistently.
  2. Limit read/write permissions: Assign minimal permissions for each zone of the memory store using a principle of least privilege. Ensure only authorized entitiesusers, agents, or processescan access memory zones. Configure these permissions dynamically depending on the session context, agent roles, and the operation being performed.
  3. Enforce validation mechanisms: Implement stringent validation protocols for all incoming data stored in memory. These protocols may include schema checks, cryptographic signatures, and origin verification. Reject any unvalidated or malformed data prior to storing it in the memory store or propagating it to other agents.
  4. Create session-specific separation rules: Prevent propagation of unverified knowledge between sessions. Store session-specific information in isolated memory zones and enforce garbage collection processes to clean up temporary memory data upon session termination. Ensure that data integrity between sessions is preserved and that confidential information does not leak into shared memory spaces.
  5. Restrict inter-agent knowledge sharing: Apply strict control rules to regulate the transfer of information between agents. Before allowing knowledge exchange, verify that the shared data is properly validated and matches predefined trust criteria. Use audit logs to maintain a traceable record of inter-agent communication for future analysis.
  6. Deploy monitoring tools: Introduce monitoring solutions capable of detecting anomalous behaviors such as unauthorized memory access, unexpected propagation of unvalidated data, and attempts to circumvent trust boundaries. These tools should provide real-time alerts and support automated remediation measures.

References

  • Microsoft Taxonomy of Failure Modes in Agentic AI Systems

countermeasure.name: Enforce isolation and access control
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Define per-user/session boundaries:
    • Implement logic in the Agent Memory Store ensuring each user or session operates in isolated memory environments.
    • Partition stored data such that no session can access another sessions memory store without explicit authorization.
    • Integrate user or session identifiers with strict verification mechanisms like encrypted tokens to enforce boundaries.
  2. Apply least-privilege Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):
    • Develop role definitions tailored to the various needs of users and agents accessing the memory store.
    • Restrict roles with minimal permissions necessary for operation. For instance, querying memory should have limited write/edit capability unless explicitly required.
    • Implement dynamic RBAC policies to revoke elevated privileges as soon as tasks are completed.
  3. Monitor for cross-session or unauthorized access attempts:
    • Deploy logging mechanisms to capture all access attempts to the Agent Memory Store, including timestamps, user/session IDs, and action types.
    • Configure anomaly detection algorithms to flag patterns including cross-session access or mismatched session identifiers.
    • Perform periodic audits of memory usage logs to identify suspicious activity and take necessary remediation steps (e.g., session invalidation, privilege revocation).
    • Trigger alerts for unauthorized access attempts or privilege escalations, and integrate response protocols with SIEM systems.
  4. Implement additional mitigation controls:
    • Encrypt stored memory at the session level to safeguard data in case of unauthorized access.
    • Set expiration policies for memory related to inactive sessions, preventing prolonged exposure to potential threats.
    • Apply input validation and sanitization on all data interfacing with the Agent Memory Store to prevent injection attacks.

References

  • Top 10 Agentic AI Security Risks: Key Threats and Mitigation Strategies

countermeasure.name: Filter and control external inputs
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Separate Instructions from Data:
    • Segment memory storage into distinct zones dedicated either to instructions or to data, ensuring these areas are isolated in both software logic and hardware architecture.
    • Utilize hardware-level protection mechanisms such as non-executable memory regions (e.g., NX bit or DEP - Data Execution Prevention) to prevent execution of data masquerading as instructions.
    • Integrate runtime monitoring within the Agent Memory Store to detect and mitigate unauthorized execution attempts by analyzing memory access patterns and preventing any injection-type exploitation events.
  2. Validate External Content Before Persistence:
    • Implement strict content validation mechanisms for any data originating externally before it is stored in persistent memory.
    • Use schema validation tools, regular expressions, and formalized data formats (e.g., JSON or XML validators) to reject malformed or unsafe data inputs.
    • Apply XPIA principles (Cross Process Isolation Application) to ensure separation of data validation logic from direct memory interactions, enabling stricter governance over input sanitization processes.
    • Adopt cryptographic techniques like HMAC or digital signatures to verify data integrity and authenticity before writing data to memory, preventing tampered data from persisting.
  3. Gate Autonomous Memorization with Approval or Automated Validation Checks:
    • Construct an approval mechanism where human oversight or predefined automated policies govern whether new information can be autonomously added to the Agent Memory Store.
    • Define clear rules for identifying "safe" versus "risky" autonomous memorization behaviors, with validation checks involving anomaly detection, rule-based logic, or machine learning models trained to detect harmful patterns.
    • Implement augmented logs and audit trails to monitor decision-making processes for autonomous memorization, ensuring transparency and traceability of approval outcomes.
    • Utilize sandboxing techniques before allowing any autonomous memorization of untrusted inputs, ensuring provisional data is tested in isolated environments before persistence.

References

  • Taxonomy of Failure Mode in Agentic AI Systems

countermeasure.name: Monitor and audit memory operations
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Enable Continuous Monitoring Tools: Integrate advanced monitoring tools capable of tracking memory usage metrics and write frequency. Utilize solutions such as cloud-based logging systems or endpoint monitoring agents to observe agent memory growth over time and detect any unusual behavior.
    • Configure thresholds for acceptable memory limits and write frequencies.
    • Set alerts to be triggered if the memory exceeds the thresholds or if unexpected memory spikes occur.
    • Ensure that monitoring dashboards provide real-time data visualization for immediate response.
  2. Enforce Session Timeouts: Configure session timeout policies to limit the duration an agent memory store is active. This minimizes the exposure window for unauthorized access or exploitation.
    • Define a parameter for session duration based on your organization's typical operational needs.
    • Implement session cleanup mechanisms to clear transient or volatile memory once the session is terminated.
    • Combine session timeouts with authentication mechanisms to ensure proper session validation on re-access.
  3. Automate Snapshot and Rollback Procedures: To recover from anomalies, set up a system that periodically creates snapshots of the agent memory store. These snapshots should act as recovery points for rollback purposes should vulnerabilities or corruption be detected.
    • Choose a snapshot frequency based on the volatility of memory changes within your working environment.
    • Encrypt snapshots to protect sensitive data they might contain.
    • Utilize automated rollback mechanisms that can be triggered by pre-configured anomaly detection criteria.
    • Periodically test the rollback process to ensure system reliability during an emergency recovery.

References

  • Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations

countermeasure.name: Restrict and monitor external memory writes
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Implement fine-grained authentication:
    • Define authentication policies that specify which tools and APIs are allowed to write to the memory store.
    • Enforce role-based access control (RBAC) or attribute-based access control (ABAC) to restrict unauthorized write operations.
    • Use secure methods such as OAuth2 or token-based authentication to validate tool and API interactions with the memory store.
    • Regularly audit authentication policies to adapt to evolving security needs and prevent privilege escalation attacks.
  2. Sandbox external components:
    • Deploy virtualization or containerization technologies (e.g., Docker or Kubernetes) to isolate external components interacting with the memory store.
    • Monitor sandboxed components for any anomalous behavior, such as unauthorized attempts to write to protected regions of memory.
    • Enable limitations on network and memory access for sandboxed applications to prevent unintended data exposure or manipulation.
    • Periodically review and update sandbox configurations to maintain alignment with security best practices.
  3. Log all write operations with forensic detail:
    • Utilize a secure centralized logging system to record all write operations to the memory store, including details like timestamp, initiating component, and data payload.
    • Apply cryptographic integrity checks (e.g., hashing) to ensure logged data is tamper-proof and traceable.
    • Enable real-time alerts for suspicious or high-frequency write operations to facilitate rapid incident response.
    • Retain logs according to compliance requirements and ensure log data can be queried for forensic investigations when needed.

By applying these steps, the Agent Memory Store will be safeguarded against unauthorized access and manipulation, reducing the potential for security breaches.

References

  • Agentic AI - Threats and Mitigations

countermeasure.name: Validate and verify memory integrity
countermeasure.desc:
To secure the Agent Memory Store against tampering and anomalies, implement the following measures:

  1. Automated Anomaly Scans: Integrate tools and frameworks capable of periodic and real-time anomaly detection tailored to memory store activity. Leverage machine learning models that can identify abnormal access patterns, unexpected state changes, or malicious payloads within memory entries. Set thresholds and alerts to notify administrators of unusual activity for immediate investigation.
  2. Enforce Cryptographic Checksums: Implement cryptographic hashes (e.g., SHA-256) for every stored memory entry. Upon storage or any modification of data, calculate and store its checksum separately. During data read operations, recompute the checksum and verify that it matches the previously stored value to ensure data integrity and detect tampering.
  3. Version Control: Deploy version tracking tools within the memory store to log every write operation. Maintain historical audit trails for memory entries with metadata including timestamps, user identity, and origin of change. This ensures traceability and helps restore legitimate versions if anomalies or tampering are detected.
  4. Rollback Capabilities: Implement a rollback mechanism that retrieves previous memory entry versions from the version control system. Automated triggers can perform rollbacks when anomalies or integrity violations are flagged by anomaly detection systems or checksum operations. Rollback systems should integrate seamlessly with access control layers to prevent malicious or unauthorized activations.
  5. Regular Verification and Testing: Conduct routine tests to evaluate the effectiveness of anomaly detection, checksum validation, and rollback mechanisms. Simulate tampering scenarios to assess the system's response and recovery speed. Optimize algorithms based on test feedback and refine detection thresholds for better accuracy over time.

References

  • Agentic AI - Threats and Mitigations

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Leak or misuse memory across sessions and users
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper isolation or uncontrolled autonomy in memory management may result in the leakage of sensitive content between users or sessions, or retention of data longer than permitted. This exposes the system to privacy violations, compliance issues, or potential privilege escalation risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious users, rogue applications, or improperly configured systems could exploit deficiencies in isolation mechanisms or retention policies to gain unauthorized access to sensitive memory.
Impacts
Exposure of confidential information, regulatory non-compliance, and unauthorized elevation of privileges that could lead to broader compromise of system integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A flaw in memory allocation causes a web application to inadvertently share session data between users, revealing private information such as authentication tokens. 2. A configuration oversight allows sensitive memory contents to persist beyond their intended lifecycle, enabling an attacker to retrieve outdated data, such as user credentials.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1098 - Account Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0048.003 - User Harm

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Exploit uncontrolled or adversarial memory inputs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Agents may autonomously memorize attacker instructions inserted through indirect methods, leading to the storage of untrusted commands that can subsequently manipulate their autonomous behavior and decision-making processes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers leveraging indirect prompt injection techniques, such as embedding malicious instructions within external resources or user-provided content, to influence an agents memory storage mechanisms.
Impacts
Compromised autonomy in agent behavior, potential execution of malicious tasks, decreased reliability of decision-making processes, and erosion of trust in the systems integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker embeds a malicious instruction in a document that an agent is programmed to analyze. The agent memorizes and stores the untrusted command, which later prompts autonomous execution of unauthorized actions. Another scenario involves an agent interacting with manipulated user inputs on a webpage, causing it to store directives that influence its functionality in undesirable ways.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1659 - Content Injection||ATLAS - AML.T0051.001 - Indirect

threat.name: Compromise memory through abnormal growth or access patterns
threat.desc:
General threat description
Memory overflow, excessive retention, or abnormal modification frequency can signal a potential compromise, leading to corrupted states, stale contexts, or the bypassing of security controls.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may attempt to exploit memory management vulnerabilities by triggering overflow conditions, retaining excessive data, or manipulating memory modification frequencies to disrupt normal operations or gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
These vulnerabilities can result in unstable system states, outdated or irrelevant data context, and security control deficiencies, potentially allowing unauthorized actions or escalating compromise.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious actor may intentionally cause high-frequency updates to memory storage to bypass data validation protocols. Another scenario could involve an adversary inducing memory overflow to overwrite critical context data, leading to degraded system functionality and compromised defenses.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055 - Process Injection||ATLAS - AML.T0016 - Obtain Capabilities||ATLAS - AML.T0031 - Erode AI Model Integrity

threat.name: Poison or manipulate stored memory
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers can inject malicious or misleading content into the Agent Memory Store, leading to corruption of long-term memory. This can adversely impact reasoning, planning, or decision-making processes, either directly or through external tools/APIs.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Injection through APIs or external tools, exploitation of insecure data management processes, or direct access vulnerabilities in the memory store system.
Impacts
Compromised system integrity, distorted decision-making, operational disruption, and the potential for cascading failures across dependent systems.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits weak API authentication to inject false data into the memory store, creating inaccuracies in systems relying on it. 2. External tools used by the Agent Memory Store are compromised, resulting in corrupted entries that influence reasoning and planning.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.

  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.
