countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

component.name: Help/ Support Center
component.desc: Help/ Support Center component in IriusRisk, replacing Zendesk.

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-601
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect') A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks. An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance. Whether this issue poses a vulnerability will be subject to the intended behavior of the application. For example, a search engine might intentionally provide redirects to arbitrary URLs.

countermeasure.name: Implement anti-phishing tools and user awareness training
countermeasure.desc:
To protect users from phishing attacks targeting the Help/Support Center, deploy anti-phishing tools and conduct user awareness training.

  • Use email filtering and anti-phishing solutions to detect and block phishing emails before they reach users.
  • Implement domain-based email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) to prevent email spoofing.
  • Educate users on recognizing phishing attempts, particularly those impersonating the Help/Support Center, and encourage them to verify the legitimacy of support communications.
  • Monitor and respond quickly to reports of phishing attempts, and take down malicious sites or email campaigns as quickly as possible.

SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and CAPTCHA for the Help/Support Center
countermeasure.desc:
To protect against denial of service attacks, implement rate limiting and CAPTCHA mechanisms in the Help/Support Center.

  • Apply rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be made to the Help/Support Center from a single IP address within a specified timeframe.
  • Integrate CAPTCHA to require users to prove they are not automated bots before submitting a support request, reducing the likelihood of automated attacks.
  • Monitor the system for signs of abuse, such as an unusually high volume of requests, and take action to block or mitigate the attack.
  • Ensure that the Help/Support Center is robust and can handle spikes in traffic without becoming unresponsive.

reference.name: Best Practices for Protecting Web Services from Denial of Service Attacks

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and access controls for Support Center
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthorized access to the Help/Support Center, implement strong authentication mechanisms and strict access controls.

  • Enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all support center agents and administrators.
  • Implement role-based access control (RBAC) to limit access to sensitive data based on the user's role within the organization.
  • Monitor and log all access to support tickets and user data, regularly reviewing logs for any unauthorized access attempts.
  • Regularly update and patch the support center platform to address security vulnerabilities.

PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Secure communication channels for the Support Center
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent data leakage, secure all communication channels used by the Help/Support Center.

  • Ensure that all communication between users and support agents is encrypted using strong encryption protocols (e.g., TLS) to protect data in transit.
  • Regularly update and patch communication platforms to address vulnerabilities that could be exploited to intercept communications.
  • Implement monitoring to detect and respond to any unauthorized access or data leakage incidents.
  • Educate support agents on the importance of using secure communication methods and recognizing potential security risks.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Use generic error messages to prevent information disclosure
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent information disclosure through verbose error messages, use generic error messages in the Help/Support Center that do not reveal specific details about the system or user accounts.

  • Ensure that all error messages returned by the Help/Support Center are generic and do not provide specific information about the internal workings of the system or the validity of user inputs.
  • Avoid providing detailed information about system errors, account status, or other internal details in error messages.
  • Implement logging and monitoring to detect and investigate patterns of requests that may indicate enumeration attempts, even if generic messages are used.
  • Periodically review error messages for potential information leakage and update them to reduce the risk of disclosure.

reference.name: Best Practices for Error Handling and Information Disclosure

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Abuse of the Help/Support Center for denial of service attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

An attacker may abuse the Help/Support Center by overwhelming it with requests, leading to a denial of service (DoS) that prevents legitimate users from receiving timely support. This can disrupt the service and damage user trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who use automated tools to flood the support center with requests. Attack vectors may involve botnets generating large volumes of traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the support system to create excessive load.

Impacts

A denial of service attack on the Help/Support Center can prevent legitimate users from accessing support services, leading to user frustration, reduced trust, and potential financial loss due to unresolved issues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses a botnet to send thousands of requests to the Help/Support Center, overwhelming the system and causing it to become unresponsive.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the ticketing system to generate an excessive number of tickets, leading to a denial of service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Information disclosure through verbose error messages in the Help/Support Center
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The Help/Support Center may return verbose error messages that provide attackers with valuable information, such as the internal workings of the system or whether an account or issue exists. This information can be used to target specific accounts or exploit vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who exploit verbose error messages to gather information about the system or specific users. Attack vectors may involve submitting crafted requests to the Help/Support Center and analyzing the responses for clues.

Impacts

Verbose error messages can inadvertently disclose sensitive information, making it easier for attackers to target specific users or exploit the system. This can lead to increased risk of further attacks, such as phishing or account takeover.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker submits a support request with a crafted input and receives a verbose error message that reveals information about the systems internal structure or user accounts.
  • An attacker uses the Help/Support Center to determine whether an email address is associated with a valid account by analyzing the differences in error messages returned for valid and invalid inputs.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to support tickets and user data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Support centers often handle sensitive user data, including personal information and details about technical issues. Unauthorized access to this data, either through compromised accounts or security flaws, can lead to data breaches, identity theft, or misuse of confidential information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who exploit vulnerabilities in the support center platform, compromised credentials, or insiders with malicious intent. Attack vectors may involve phishing, brute-force attacks, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

Impacts

Unauthorized access to support tickets and user data can result in the exposure of confidential information, leading to privacy violations, financial loss, and damage to the organizations reputation. It may also compromise the integrity of support operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker gains access to a support agent's account and retrieves sensitive information from user support tickets.
  • An insider with access to the support center extracts user data and sells it to a third party.

threat.name: Data leakage through insecure communication channels in the support center
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Communication channels used in the Help/Support Center, such as chat, email, or ticketing systems, may not be properly secured, leading to potential data leakage. Sensitive information exchanged during support interactions could be intercepted, leading to privacy violations or unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who intercept unencrypted communication, insiders who misuse access to communication data, or vulnerabilities in the communication platform itself. Attack vectors may involve network sniffing, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploiting flaws in communication protocols.

Impacts

Data leakage through insecure communication channels can result in the exposure of confidential user information, leading to identity theft, financial loss, and regulatory penalties. It can also undermine user trust in the organizations support services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker intercepts unencrypted support emails containing sensitive user information, gaining access to confidential data.
  • A vulnerability in the chat platform allows an attacker to eavesdrop on support conversations, leading to data leakage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Phishing attack targeting users seeking support
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers may impersonate the Help/Support Center to launch phishing attacks, tricking users into providing sensitive information or credentials under the guise of resolving an issue. This can lead to unauthorized access to user accounts, identity theft, and data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who create fake support emails, websites, or chat sessions that mimic the legitimate Help/Support Center. Attack vectors include email phishing, spoofed websites, and fraudulent support calls or chat sessions.

Impacts

Successful phishing attacks can lead to compromised user accounts, unauthorized access to personal data, and potential financial loss. They can also erode trust in the organizations support services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker sends a phishing email pretending to be from the Help/Support Center, asking the user to log in to resolve an issue, but the link directs the user to a fake site that captures their credentials.
  • A fake chat session is initiated by an attacker posing as a support agent, tricking the user into revealing sensitive information.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

  • A new type of long-lived key on AWS: Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

  • AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy reference

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

countermeasure.name: Conduct regular vulnerability assessments
countermeasure.desc:
Conduct assessments on packages and all integration points, as well as potentially dangerous functionality, e.g., code interpreter, to identify and mitigate security gaps.

Implementation Steps:

1. Identify and Catalog All Components
  • Step 1: Create a comprehensive inventory of all software components, packages, and integration points within your LLM framework, including third-party libraries and APIs.
  • Step 2: Identify potentially dangerous functionalities, such as code interpreters or direct code execution features, that may introduce security risks.
  • Step 3: Regularly update this inventory to account for any new components or changes in the system architecture.
2. Perform Regular Vulnerability Scanning
  • Step 1: Integrate automated vulnerability scanning tools (e.g., OWASP Dependency-Check, Snyk, or Anchore) into your CI/CD pipeline to scan all packages and libraries for known vulnerabilities.
  • Step 2: Conduct dynamic and static analysis of code, especially around critical functionalities like code interpreters, using tools such as SonarQube, Fortify, or Veracode.
  • Step 3: Schedule regular manual code reviews and penetration testing sessions to complement automated scans, focusing on high-risk areas and custom code.
3. Assess and Mitigate Identified Vulnerabilities
  • Step 1: Prioritize identified vulnerabilities based on their severity and potential impact on the LLM framework's security. Use risk assessment frameworks like CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) for this purpose.
  • Step 2: Develop and implement mitigation strategies, such as patching, code refactoring, or disabling risky functionalities, to address critical vulnerabilities immediately.
  • Step 3: Re-scan the system after applying fixes to ensure that vulnerabilities have been successfully mitigated and no new issues have been introduced.
4. Continuous Monitoring and Reassessment
  • Step 1: Implement continuous monitoring of the system to detect new vulnerabilities or changes in the threat landscape. Use tools like Dependabot or GitHub Security Alerts for real-time updates.
  • Step 2: Establish a regular reassessment schedule to ensure that all components are periodically reviewed for new vulnerabilities, especially after significant updates or changes in functionality.
  • Step 3: Maintain an incident response plan to quickly address any critical vulnerabilities that are discovered between regular assessments.

By following these steps, you can systematically identify, assess, and mitigate security gaps within your LLM framework, ensuring a robust defense against potential vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure sourcing of dependencies
countermeasure.desc:
Setup a security process to safeguard against dependency exploitation by focusing on stringent validation, continuous monitoring, and secure sourcing of third-party dependencies.

Key Features and Implementation Steps:

1. Automated Dependency Validation:
  • Step 1: Integrate automated security tools into your build pipeline. Popular tools include OWASP Dependency-Check, Snyk, or WhiteSource.
  • Step 2: Configure these tools to perform regular scans of all dependencies for known vulnerabilities using databases like the National Vulnerability Database (NVD) and GitHub Security Advisories.
  • Step 3: Set up static and dynamic analysis of codebases to detect malicious code within dependencies. Tools such as SonarQube or Veracode can be valuable here.
2. Cryptographic Signing:
  • Step 1: Ensure that all dependencies are sourced from repositories that support cryptographic signing (e.g., Maven Central, npm).
  • Step 2: Verify the cryptographic signatures of all downloaded dependencies. Tools like GPG or sigstore can assist in verifying signatures.
  • Step 3: Implement a policy that blocks the use of any dependencies without valid signatures.
3. Contextual Scanning and Monitoring:
  • Step 1: Set up continuous security scanning of dependencies using tools like Dependabot or Renovate.
  • Step 2: Employ runtime behavior monitoring tools such as Falco or Sysdig to detect anomalous activities within dependencies after integration.
  • Step 3: Implement alert mechanisms for newly disclosed vulnerabilities and unusual dependency behavior.
4. Controlled Repository Access:
  • Step 1: Restrict access to code repositories to only authorized personnel using role-based access controls (RBAC).
  • Step 2: Ensure that all dependencies are sourced from reputable and secure repositories such as npm, PyPI, Maven Central, etc.
  • Step 3: Enforce repository access policies that validate the integrity and reputation of the dependency sources.
5. Dependency Manifest Locking:
  • Step 1: Use dependency lock files (e.g., package-lock.json, yarn.lock) to freeze the versions of dependencies used in the builds.
  • Step 2: Regularly audit and update lock files to incorporate security patches and stable versions.
  • Step 3: Implement CI/CD pipeline rules to reject builds without up-to-date and validated lock files.
6. Supply Chain Governance:
  • Step 1: Develop and enforce security policies that only allow contributions from trusted sources or individuals.
  • Step 2: Conduct regular audits of open-source contributions for any security inconsistencies or backdoors.
  • Step 3: Maintain a whitelist of acceptable sources or maintainers for critical dependencies and monitor for any changes in their security posture.
7. Machine Learning Anomaly Detection:
  • Step 1: Integrate machine learning-based security tools like AnomalyDetector or ThreatML that can identify unusual patterns in dependency behavior.
  • Step 2: Train these models using valid and attack dataset scenarios to improve their detection accuracy.
  • Step 3: Continuously monitor, evaluate, and update these models to adapt to new threat landscapes.
8. Awareness and Training:
  • Step 1: Organize regular training sessions for development and DevOps teams on dependency security.
  • Step 2: Provide resources and materials on the risks associated with third-party components and how to mitigate them.
  • Step 3: Establish regular security drills and mock exercises to reinforce learning and preparedness.

By meticulously following the above steps, developers and DevOps teams can deploy Dependency Integrity Guardian effectively and significantly mitigate risks associated with third-party dependencies, thus fortifying their software supply chain against dependency exploitation attacks.

countermeasure.name: Ensure the data pipeline is secured and monitored
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data within the pipeline is encrypted both at rest and in transit to protect against unauthorized access. Pipeline auditing should also be implemented by logging and monitoring data pipeline activities to detect anomalies or unauthorized access. Also restrict access to the data pipeline to authorized entities only, using strong authentication mechanisms.

Implementation Steps:

1. Data Encryption
  • Step 1: Implement encryption for all data stored within the pipeline using strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256). Ensure that encryption keys are securely managed using a Key Management Service (KMS) such as AWS KMS or HashiCorp Vault.
  • Step 2: Use TLS (Transport Layer Security) to encrypt data in transit between components of the pipeline. Ensure that TLS certificates are properly configured and regularly updated.
  • Step 3: Perform regular encryption audits to ensure that all data remains encrypted and that no sensitive data is inadvertently exposed in plaintext form.
2. Pipeline Auditing and Monitoring
  • Step 1: Set up logging for all data pipeline activities, including data access, transfers, and transformations. Use centralized logging systems like ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Splunk for efficient log management.
  • Step 2: Implement continuous monitoring of the data pipeline using tools like Prometheus or Datadog to detect and alert on anomalies, such as unusual data access patterns or failed data transfers.
  • Step 3: Regularly review audit logs and monitoring alerts to identify potential security incidents. Ensure that logs are securely stored and protected from tampering.
3. Access Control
  • Step 1: Restrict access to the data pipeline to authorized entities only by implementing Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). Assign the minimum required permissions to each role.
  • Step 2: Use multi-factor authentication (MFA) to secure access to the pipeline management interfaces and data stores. Ensure that all users and systems interacting with the pipeline are authenticated using strong, cryptographic credentials.
  • Step 3: Regularly audit access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel and systems have access to the data pipeline. Revoke access promptly when no longer needed or when an employee leaves the organization.

By following these steps, you can secure your data pipeline effectively, ensuring that data is protected from unauthorized access and that pipeline activities are continuously monitored for security incidents.

countermeasure.name: Secure integration and configuration processes
countermeasure.desc:
Secure API integrations and configurations by ensuring that all API calls use secure communication protocols (e.g., HTTPS) and that API keys and credentials are securely managed. Also, implement strict validation of inputs coming from and going to external APIs to prevent injection attacks or data leakage. Use RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) to limit API access based on user roles, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access.

Use the following practices and guidelines which are aimed at ensuring that all software and hardware systems are configured securely. The steps below will help you establish a formal Secure Configuration Management Protocol in your development and operational workflow:

  • Baseline Configurations:
    • Define security requirements using standards like CIS and NIST.
    • Document and enforce least privilege in system setups.
    • Automate deployment with tools like Ansible, updating regularly.
  • Audits and Assessments:
    • Schedule regular audits and use tools like Nessus to ensure compliance.
    • Conduct risk assessments and prioritize mitigation.
  • Change Management:
    • Implement a change control process with security reviews.
    • Track and validate changes using version control and staging environments.
  • Monitoring and Response:
    • Continuously monitor (e.g., using SIEM tools).
    • Perform post-incident analysis to improve configurations.
  • Training:
    • Regularly train staff on secure configuration management and update guides.

These steps would ensure a secure system configuration management.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Adversaries exploit weak dependency management and/or vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In the context of software frameworks, adversaries may exploit weaknesses in dependency management processes or vulnerabilities within third-party or internally developed packages. Modern software development often relies heavily on external libraries, modules, and frameworks to accelerate development and leverage community-tested functionality. However, this reliance introduces significant risks. A single compromised dependency can act as an entry point for attackers, potentially leading to widespread system compromise. These dependencies, often sourced from various third-party repositories, may not always undergo rigorous security vetting and could contain inherent vulnerabilities, or worse, be deliberately malicious with embedded backdoors or exploitative code.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals: Attackers aiming to infiltrate systems for data theft, ransomware deployment, or other malicious activities.
  • Nation-State Actors: Government-funded groups targeting critical infrastructure or engaging in cyber espionage.
  • Insiders: Malicious individuals within an organization who introduce compromised or vulnerable dependencies.
  • Hacktivists: Individuals motivated by ideology who exploit vulnerabilities to advance their cause.

Attack vectors include:

  • Inserting Malicious Code in Open-Source Projects: Attackers contribute to open-source projects with hidden malicious code, which later gets integrated into larger projects.
  • Poisoning Software Repositories: Compromising popular repositories (e.g., npm, PyPI) to distribute malicious versions of commonly used libraries.
  • Dependency Confusion: Creating malicious libraries with the same names as internal libraries, tricking automated systems into downloading and using the malicious versions.
  • Exploiting Known Vulnerabilities: Identifying and exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities in widely used dependencies.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exfiltration of sensitive and confidential data, leading to privacy violations and potential regulatory penalties.
  • System Compromise: Unauthorized access and control over systems, which can be used to further propagate attacks or disrupt operations.
  • Service Disruptions: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks that impact the availability and reliability of critical services.
  • Financial Loss: Costs incurred from breach responses, fines, legal actions, and potential loss of business.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust among customers, partners, and stakeholders, potentially resulting in long-term brand damage.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Stealing of proprietary algorithms, business plans, or other valuable intellectual property.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malicious Module in Package Repositories: An attacker creates a malicious module and publishes it on a popular package repository like npm or PyPI. The module mimics a legitimate one, leading developers to unknowingly integrate it into their projects. Once in use, the module can exfiltrate sensitive data or create backdoors for future exploitation.
  2. Supply Chain Attack via Open-Source Libraries: A widely-used open-source library is maintained by volunteers. An attacker offers assistance and, after gaining trust, inserts malicious code into an update. When organizations update to the latest version, they unknowingly incorporate the exploit into their software, which could lead to extensive system compromise.
  3. Dependency Confusion: An attacker identifies internal project dependency names used by a target organization and creates malicious versions with the same names on public repositories. Due to mishandled dependency resolution or configuration errors, the organization's build systems fetch and incorporate the malicious public versions, leading to potential breaches.
  4. Exploiting a Known Vulnerability: An older version of a popular framework is known to have a vulnerability, but the target organization has not yet applied the necessary updates. An attacker exploits this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code on the target system, leading to full system compromise and potential lateral movement within the network.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Adversaries exploit insecure API integrations or misconfigurations, including in orchestration/workflow
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In LLM frameworks, adversaries can exploit insecure API integrations or misconfigurations, including in orchestration and workflow processes. These frameworks often depend on APIs to integrate various services and components, such as databases and external APIs, to function efficiently. However, improper configurations or insecure usage of these APIs can create significant security vulnerabilities. Additionally, orchestration and workflow tools that coordinate the execution of tasks within these frameworks can be misconfigured, leading to exposure of sensitive data, unauthorized access, or unintended system behaviors. Such misconfigurations can be particularly dangerous as they often go unnoticed until a compromise occurs, enabling attackers to exploit these weaknesses over time.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Script Kiddies: Inexperienced attackers using automated tools to discover and exploit common API misconfigurations or insecure default settings.
  • Cybercriminals: Skilled adversaries who target misconfigured APIs or orchestration settings to gain unauthorized access, steal data, or disrupt services.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors with knowledge of the internal configurations who may exploit misconfigurations for personal gain or sabotage.
  • Automated Bots: Tools and scripts that scan networks for misconfigured APIs or workflow systems to exploit them.

Attack vectors for this threat include:

  • Exposed API Endpoints: Unprotected or improperly secured APIs that are accessible over the internet, providing a direct entry point for attackers.
  • Orchestration/Workflow Misconfigurations: Incorrect settings in orchestration that lead to unauthorized access or unintended task executions.
  • Default Credentials and Open Ports: Use of default credentials or open management interfaces that are not properly secured, allowing easy access to attackers.
  • Overly Permissive Access Controls: APIs or workflow tools with overly permissive access controls, enabling unauthorized access to critical systems or data.
  • Improper API Authentication/Authorization: Misconfigured authentication or authorization mechanisms that fail to adequately protect API endpoints.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, potentially leading to financial loss, regulatory penalties, and reputational damage.
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degradation of critical services due to exploitation of misconfigured APIs or workflows, impacting business operations.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with incident response, legal actions, regulatory fines, and potential loss of business opportunities.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Theft of proprietary data, algorithms, or trade secrets, undermining competitive advantage.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of industry regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS, resulting in legal consequences and penalties.
  • Spread of Malware: Using compromised APIs or workflows as vectors to distribute malware within an organization or to external targets.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exposed API Endpoint in Orchestration: A developer misconfigures an API endpoint within a workflow, leaving it publicly accessible without proper authentication. An attacker discovers the unprotected endpoint via automated scanning and uses it to inject malicious commands, leading to unauthorized data access and workflow disruptions.
  2. Default Credentials in API Gateway: An organization deploys an API gateway but fails to change the default administrative credentials. An attacker exploits this oversight to gain full control over the gateway, redirecting traffic, stealing API keys, and accessing backend systems.
  3. Unsecured API Key in Source Code: A developer mistakenly commits an API key to a public GitHub repository. An attacker finds the exposed key, uses it to access the API, and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in the backend database.
  4. Overly Permissive Workflow Automation: A workflow automation tool is configured with overly permissive settings, allowing any authenticated user to trigger high-privilege tasks. An insider with limited access uses this loophole to escalate privileges, causing data leaks and system disruptions.

reference.name: Secure API Management for LLM-Based Services

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Adversaries exploit weak data pipeline security
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

LLM frameworks are designed to manage complex data pipelines where data is ingested, transformed, processed, and transmitted between various components and services. These pipelines are critical to the functionality and accuracy of machine learning models and AI-driven applications. However, if the security of these data pipelines is weak, adversaries can exploit vulnerabilities to intercept, manipulate, or corrupt data at various stages of the pipeline. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data breaches, or the introduction of malicious data that can compromise the integrity of the entire system. Ensuring robust security measures throughout the data pipeline is crucial to maintaining the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the data being processed.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals: Skilled attackers targeting data pipelines to steal sensitive information, inject malicious data, or disrupt operations.
  • Nation-State Actors: Government-affiliated groups aiming to compromise data pipelines for espionage or sabotage purposes.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors with knowledge of the data pipeline architecture who may exploit vulnerabilities for personal gain or to cause harm.
  • Hacktivists: Ideologically motivated individuals or groups seeking to expose or disrupt systems by compromising data pipelines.
  • Automated Bots: Scripts and tools designed to scan for and exploit common vulnerabilities in data pipelines, such as unsecured endpoints or weak encryption.

Attack vectors for exploiting weak data pipeline security include:

  • Data Interception: Attacking unencrypted data streams within the pipeline to capture sensitive information.
  • Injection Attacks: Introducing malicious data into the pipeline to corrupt the data processing and model training phases.
  • Unauthorized Access: Exploiting weak authentication and access controls to gain unauthorized entry into the pipeline components.
  • Misconfiguration Exploitation: Leveraging poorly configured data pipelines to reroute or modify data flows.
  • Supply Chain Attacks: Compromising third-party components or libraries integrated into the data pipeline to introduce vulnerabilities.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive or proprietary data leading to significant financial and reputational damage.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Introduction of corrupted or malicious data that undermines the reliability and accuracy of AI models.
  • Service Disruption: Interruptions in data flow or processing can cause downtime or degradation of AI-driven services.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with data breach response, legal actions, regulatory fines, and potential business disruption.
  • Regulatory Compliance Violations: Exposure of personally identifiable information (PII) or other regulated data, leading to penalties and legal consequences.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Theft of sensitive data, algorithms, or proprietary processes via compromised data pipelines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Data Interception via Unsecured Channels: An organization transmits sensitive customer data through a data pipeline without proper encryption. An attacker intercepts this data during transit, leading to a significant data breach that exposes personal and financial information.
  2. Injection of Malicious Data: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a component of the data pipeline and injects malicious data into the training dataset of a machine learning model. The model is then trained on this corrupted data, leading to inaccurate predictions and unreliable outputs.
  3. Exploitation of Weak Access Controls: A former employee with lingering access credentials exploits weak access control mechanisms to re-enter the data pipeline. The attacker modifies the data being processed, resulting in data corruption and the potential compromise of the AI-driven decision-making process.
  4. Misconfiguration of Data Routing: A misconfigured data pipeline reroutes sensitive data to an insecure storage location. An attacker discovers and exploits this vulnerability to exfiltrate confidential information, leading to a breach of regulatory compliance and significant financial penalties.
  5. Supply Chain Attack on Data Processing Library: An attacker compromises a third-party library that is widely used in data pipelines. By introducing a backdoor into the library, the attacker gains access to data processing systems across multiple organizations, enabling widespread data theft and manipulation.

reference.name: Common Mistakes in Data pipelines and How to Avoid Them - Apache Airflow Example

threat.name: Adversaries may execute arbitrary code or access sensitive data via insecure functionality
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

LLM frameworks, which are designed to streamline the development and deployment of large language models, may inadvertently expose functionality that can be exploited by adversaries to execute arbitrary code or access sensitive data. These frameworks may contain vulnerabilities commonly associated with web applications and exposed services, such as Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF), Path Traversal, SQL Injection (SQLi), Remote Code Execution (RCE), and other critical security flaws. If not properly secured, these vulnerabilities can provide attackers with direct access to the underlying system, allowing them to execute unauthorized commands, access or manipulate sensitive data, and potentially compromise the integrity and availability of the entire framework.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals: Attackers who exploit vulnerabilities to execute malicious code, steal data, or disrupt services for financial gain or to cause harm.
  • Nation-State Actors: Highly skilled adversaries targeting critical infrastructure or sensitive data through sophisticated exploitation techniques.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors with access to the system who might exploit known vulnerabilities for personal gain or sabotage.
  • Hacktivists: Ideologically motivated individuals or groups seeking to expose vulnerabilities or disrupt operations by exploiting insecure functionality.
  • Automated Bots: Tools and scripts designed to scan and exploit common vulnerabilities in web applications and exposed services.

Attack vectors for this threat include:

  • Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF): Exploiting the server's ability to make unauthorized requests to internal or external resources, potentially bypassing access controls.
  • Path Traversal: Manipulating file paths to gain unauthorized access to files outside the intended directory, potentially exposing sensitive information or executing commands.
  • SQL Injection (SQLi): Injecting malicious SQL queries through input fields to manipulate or extract data from the database.
  • Remote Code Execution (RCE): Exploiting vulnerabilities that allow attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server, gaining control over the system.
  • Unvalidated Input: Leveraging improper input validation to inject malicious data or commands that compromise system integrity.

Impacts

  • System Compromise: Full control of the affected system, allowing the attacker to execute commands, install malware, or alter system behavior.
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data, leading to financial loss, reputational damage, and potential regulatory penalties.
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degradation of services due to exploitation of vulnerabilities, affecting business operations and user experience.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with breach response, legal actions, regulatory fines, and potential loss of business opportunities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust among customers, partners, and stakeholders due to the exposure of vulnerabilities or the occurrence of successful attacks.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Theft of proprietary algorithms, models, or data that can undermine competitive advantage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via Unsecured API: An attacker exploits an SSRF vulnerability in a poorly secured API endpoint within the LLM framework. The attacker uses this flaw to make unauthorized requests to internal systems, eventually gaining access to sensitive data stored on the server.
  2. Path Traversal Attack on File Upload Functionality: A developer implements a file upload feature in the framework but fails to properly sanitize the input paths. An attacker exploits this oversight by crafting a request that accesses files outside the intended directory, leading to the exposure of sensitive configuration files.
  3. SQL Injection via Unvalidated User Input: A web interface integrated with the LLM framework fails to properly validate user input in a search field. An attacker injects malicious SQL queries through this field, compromising the underlying database and extracting sensitive user data.
  4. Remote Code Execution (RCE) through Malicious Payload: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in a web service exposed by the LLM framework that allows for the execution of arbitrary code. By sending a specially crafted request, the attacker gains remote control over the server, enabling them to execute commands and compromise the entire system.
  5. Exploitation of Unvalidated Input in a Chatbot Interface: A chatbot built using the LLM framework does not adequately validate user inputs. An attacker exploits this flaw to inject commands that are executed by the underlying system, leading to unauthorized data access and potential system compromise.

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-131
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-131: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size The product does not correctly calculate the size to be used when allocating a buffer, which could lead to a buffer overflow.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-610
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-610: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

countermeasure.name: Apply provenance and source attribution
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Record lineage and source attribution for each memory update:
    • Integrate metadata tracking into the Agent Memory Store to capture details about the origin of each memory entry. This includes details such as the time of update, the identity of the actor (human, system, or AI tool) responsible for the update, and the source dataset or interaction.
    • Ensure any updates to memory also document any transformations or derived data processes that contribute to the update.
    • Use a standardized metadata format for lineage and source attribution to ensure interoperability and easy integration with forensic tools.
  2. Maintain immutable signed audit logs:
    • Implement a logging mechanism that uses cryptographic signatures to ensure immutability. Each log entry should be signed using private keys to prevent tampering.
    • Store logs in a tamper-proof ledger or a blockchain-based system to guarantee integrity and immutability.
    • Include contextual information in each log entry, such as the timestamp, associated memory updates, and any lineage metadata, to provide a comprehensive audit trail.
    • Establish clear access control policies for the audit logs, allowing only designated individuals or systems to access and verify them.
  3. Track knowledge lineage for forensic rollback:
    • Implement a version control mechanism in the Agent Memory Store to keep track of all previous states of memory records. This enables forensic rollback in case of memory corruption or unauthorized edits.
    • Ensure every rollback action is logged within the signed audit logs to maintain accountability and transparency.
    • Design lineage tracking to include a branching mechanism, which allows for the reconstruction of a memory's entire historical trajectory along with the sources contributing to each intermediate state.
    • Develop a user interface or API to facilitate forensic rollback and allow for auditing of memory changes at granular levels.

References

  • Record Lineage and Source Attribution in Intelligent Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1047 - Audit||ATLAS - AML.M0014 - Verify AI Artifacts

countermeasure.name: Configure retention and user oversight
countermeasure.desc:
Implementation guidelines:

  1. Apply TTL-based purging: Set up a Time-To-Live (TTL) mechanism to automatically purge memory entries after a predefined time period:
    • Analyze the sensitivity of the data stored in memory and define an appropriate TTL period (e.g., hours, days, weeks).
    • Leverage built-in TTL functionality in database systems or memory stores that support expiration policies (e.g., Redis).
    • Configure TTL settings during memory entry creation to ensure automated purging after the specified duration.
    • Implement scheduled audits to confirm that expired memory entries are successfully deleted.
  2. Encrypt memory at rest and in transit: Ensure robust encryption to protect stored and transmitted memory:
    • Utilize a secure encryption algorithm (e.g., AES-256) to encrypt memory data at rest.
    • Integrate encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher) for data transit between the memory store and its consumers.
    • Regularly rotate encryption keys using an enterprise-grade key management solution to minimize exposure to compromised keys.
    • Perform vulnerability scans and penetration testing to verify the adequacy of encryption mechanisms.
    • Define fallback procedures to mitigate incidents, such as memory decryption failures or key compromise.
  3. Provide mechanisms for users to review, correct, and delete memory entries: Introduce controls that allow users to manage stored data effectively:
    • Develop a user interface or API endpoint that enables authenticated users to view memory records associated with their identities.
    • Allow users to submit corrections via guided forms or dynamic editing options, ensuring updates follow proper validation and integrity checks.
    • Offer secure deletion functionality for users to remove unwanted or incorrect data from memory.
    • Log all review, correction, and deletion activities for audit purposes while safeguarding user privacy.
    • Educate users on data management practices, emphasizing the importance of accurate memory entries and secure deletion.

Adopting these countermeasures will mitigate risks associated with data compromise, inaccuracies, and unauthorized retention within an Agent Memory Store.

References

  • Memory Risk Framework and Mitigation Playbook for Production-Ready AI Agents

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST
