usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Search performance degradation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Search performance degradation occurs when a search system experiences slow query execution, reduced throughput, or unresponsiveness due to high load, inefficient query designs, or resource exhaustion. This impacts the user experience, potentially leading to operational disruptions or loss of trust in the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • High Query Volume: Excessive user or system-generated search requests overloading the infrastructure.
  • Inefficient Query Designs: Poorly optimized or complex search queries consuming disproportionate resources.
  • Malicious Actors: Launching denial-of-service (DoS) attacks to overload the search system.
  • Resource Constraints: Insufficient compute, memory, or storage resources allocated to the search system.

Impacts

  • Reduced System Availability: Users face delays or timeouts while executing search queries.
  • Decreased Productivity: Applications relying on the search feature become less efficient.
  • Reputation Damage: Users lose trust in the reliability of the search system.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A sudden surge in user traffic overwhelms the search system, causing slow query responses and timeouts.
  2. Inefficiently designed queries with multiple nested filters lead to high CPU and memory consumption, impacting overall system performance.
  3. A malicious actor initiates a DoS attack by sending an excessive number of concurrent search requests, rendering the system unresponsive.
  4. Insufficient resource allocation fails to scale with an increase in dataset size, degrading the search performance during peak hours.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.002 - Service Exhaustion Flood

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Search data leakage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Search data leakage occurs when sensitive or restricted information is inadvertently exposed through search queries or results. This can happen due to improper access controls, misconfigured search indices, or insufficient sanitization of data presented in search results. Attackers or unauthorized users may exploit these vulnerabilities to access sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Unauthorized Users: Exploiting poorly implemented access controls to retrieve restricted data.
  • Misconfigured Search Indices: Indices containing sensitive information are unintentionally exposed to public or unauthorized access.
  • Injection Attacks: Manipulating search queries to extract hidden or sensitive information.
  • Developers/Admins: Misconfiguring search filters or access policies.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Sensitive data, such as personal or confidential information, becomes accessible to unauthorized users.
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection laws such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of user trust due to the exposure of private or critical information.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A user queries a search system and inadvertently retrieves sensitive records due to misconfigured access filters.
  2. An attacker crafts a search query to exploit a poorly implemented security filter, exposing sensitive data from the backend.
  3. A search index containing unredacted sensitive information, such as user credentials, is exposed to the internet without proper access restrictions.
  4. Misconfigured search autocomplete functionality exposes partial sensitive data during user interactions.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of search activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Inadequate monitoring of search activities occurs when search queries, results, and user interactions are not properly logged or analyzed. This can lead to undetected malicious activities, such as unauthorized data access or system abuse, and hinder incident response and forensic investigations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Users: Exploiting the lack of monitoring to extract sensitive information or overload the system.
  • Insiders: Misusing search capabilities without triggering alerts or logs.
  • Automated Tools: Bots conducting large-scale data extraction or denial-of-service attacks unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Sensitive information may be accessed or exfiltrated without detection.
  • Operational Disruptions: Abusive search behavior can degrade system performance without raising alerts.
  • Delayed Response: Lack of monitoring hinders the identification and resolution of security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker performs a series of malicious search queries designed to bypass filters and extract sensitive information without being detected.
  2. A bot continuously sends automated search requests, overloading the system, while the absence of activity monitoring prevents early mitigation.
  3. An insider accesses restricted search data to which they should not have access, and the activity remains unnoticed due to missing audit trails.
  4. A misconfigured monitoring system fails to detect unusual search patterns indicative of a potential breach or abuse.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Search query injections
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Search query injections occur when attackers manipulate search inputs to inject malicious code or queries into a search system. This can result in unauthorized data retrieval, bypassing of access controls, or disruption of the system's functionality. Search query injection often exploits insufficient input validation or improper sanitization of user-provided data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Attackers: Crafting malicious search inputs to exploit vulnerabilities in query processing.
  • Automated Tools: Using bots to test for and exploit injection vulnerabilities.
  • Internal Users: Malicious insiders leveraging search interfaces to access unauthorized data.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Access: Sensitive or restricted information is retrieved by bypassing access controls.
  • Data Manipulation: Injected queries alter or manipulate the data presented to users.
  • System Disruption: Malicious queries can cause search engine crashes or performance degradation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker injects wildcard or filter bypass strings into a search query to retrieve sensitive data that should not be visible.
  2. Malicious inputs exploit improperly sanitized parameters in the search query to access restricted database records.
  3. A crafted search query with unexpected inputs causes a denial-of-service by overloading the system's query parser.
  4. Injection of logical operators into a search query allows an attacker to bypass access restrictions and retrieve unauthorized information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable and monitor CloudTrail logging for CloudSearch access and changes
countermeasure.desc: Enable AWS CloudTrail logging for all access and configuration changes to your AWS CloudSearch domain to ensure comprehensive monitoring and auditing of all activities. Configure CloudTrail to capture detailed logs of API calls and user interactions with the CloudSearch domain. Set up automated alerts to notify your security team of any unauthorized or suspicious activities detected in the logs. Regularly review and analyze CloudTrail logs to detect anomalies, investigate potential security incidents, and ensure compliance with security policies. This control is critical for maintaining visibility into the security of your CloudSearch environment and for responding promptly to any unauthorized access or changes.

reference.name: Logging Amazon CloudSearch Configuration API Calls with AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all data transmission to and from CloudSearch domains
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all data transmitted to and from AWS CloudSearch domains is encrypted using secure protocols, specifically HTTPS. Configure your clients and applications to enforce the use of HTTPS for all communications with CloudSearch, and reject any unencrypted (HTTP) connections. This setup prevents unauthorized interception and tampering of data during transit, protecting sensitive information and maintaining the integrity of the data exchanged with CloudSearch. Regularly audit your configurations to ensure compliance with this security standard, and update any client applications that do not support HTTPS to ensure they adhere to this requirement.

countermeasure.name: Implement data integrity verification for CloudSearch indexed data
countermeasure.desc: Use checksums or other integrity verification mechanisms to ensure that the data indexed by AWS CloudSearch remains unchanged and free from tampering. Implement automated processes to generate and compare checksums or cryptographic hashes of your indexed data before and after indexing to detect any unauthorized changes. Regularly perform integrity checks on your data to promptly identify and respond to potential tampering or corruption. Document and audit these processes to ensure consistency and reliability in maintaining data integrity. This control is essential for protecting the accuracy and trustworthiness of your search data, thereby safeguarding your CloudSearch environment from data manipulation attacks.

reference.name: Preparing Your Data for Amazon CloudSearch

countermeasure.name: Implement fine-grained access control for CloudSearch resources
countermeasure.desc: Configure resource-based policies and IAM roles to enforce fine-grained access control, ensuring that only authorized users and services can access AWS CloudSearch resources. Design these policies to align with the principle of least privilege, granting the minimum necessary permissions required for each user or service to perform their specific tasks. Regularly audit and review these access permissions to identify and revoke any excessive privileges, ensuring ongoing compliance with security best practices. This control helps prevent unauthorized access and potential misuse of CloudSearch resources, thereby enhancing the overall security of your environment.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access for CloudSearch with regular permission reviews
countermeasure.desc: Configure IAM policies and roles to grant only the minimum necessary permissions to users and services that access AWS CloudSearch. This ensures that each entity has only the access it needs to perform its tasks, reducing the risk of unauthorized actions. Regularly review and adjust these permissions to align with current operational requirements, removing any unnecessary or excessive privileges. Implement automated tools or scripts to periodically audit permissions and detect over-privileged accounts. This control helps maintain a secure environment by adhering to the principle of least privilege, thereby minimizing the attack surface and potential security risks associated with excessive permissions.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive privileges to CloudSearch resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Excessive privileges in AWS CloudSearch occur when users or services are granted more permissions than necessary, increasing the risk of unauthorized access, modification, or deletion of data and configurations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised accounts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Over-permissioned IAM roles or policies.
    • Compromised credentials with excessive privileges.
    • Misconfigured access controls.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized changes to configurations or exposure of sensitive data.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Unapproved modifications or deletions of indexed data.
  • Operational Disruption: Disruption of search functionality or service performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Account: An attacker with access to an over-permissioned account alters CloudSearch settings, leading to data exposure.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Role: A role with excessive privileges is misused to delete critical index data, causing service disruption.
  3. External Attack: An attacker exploits an over-permissioned role to access and exfiltrate sensitive data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudSearch domain
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to an AWS CloudSearch domain occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the domain without proper authorization. This can lead to unauthorized manipulation of search data, configurations, or access to sensitive information stored within the domain.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised user accounts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of weak or misconfigured access controls.
    • Compromised credentials granting unauthorized access.
    • Publicly accessible endpoints without proper restrictions.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized users can modify configurations, access sensitive data, or disrupt search services.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Alteration or deletion of indexed data, leading to incorrect search results or data loss.
  • Operational Disruption: Changes to domain settings or data can lead to service outages or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Account: An attacker uses stolen credentials to gain access to the CloudSearch domain, altering configurations and accessing sensitive data.
  2. Misconfigured Access Control: An insider with more access than necessary modifies search indexes, leading to data corruption.
  3. Public Exposure: A CloudSearch domain is unintentionally left publicly accessible, allowing unauthorized users to view or modify data.

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit occurs when sensitive information is transmitted between clients and AWS CloudSearch without encryption, making it vulnerable to interception by unauthorized parties. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive data, including search queries and results.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, network eavesdroppers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Interception of unencrypted data during transmission.
    • Exploitation of weak or misconfigured network settings that allow unencrypted communication.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive information such as search queries, user data, or proprietary content.
  • Privacy Violations: Compromise of personally identifiable information (PII) or other confidential data.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to the exposure of sensitive customer or organizational data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Eavesdropping Attack: An attacker intercepts unencrypted data transmitted between a client and the CloudSearch domain, gaining access to sensitive search queries and results.
  2. Network Sniffing: A malicious insider uses network sniffing tools to capture unencrypted data in transit, leading to the exposure of confidential information.
  3. Misconfigured Network Settings: A CloudSearch domain is configured to allow unencrypted connections, which an attacker exploits to intercept and read data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised data integrity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Compromised data integrity in AWS CloudSearch occurs when the data stored or indexed within the CloudSearch domain is tampered with, altered, or corrupted. This can lead to inaccurate search results, loss of trust in the data, and potential security risks for applications relying on the integrity of the search data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unauthorized modifications to data or configurations within the CloudSearch domain.
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the CI/CD pipeline that affect the integrity of data during indexing.
    • Injection of malicious or corrupt data into the search index.

Impacts

  • Inaccurate Search Results: Tampered data can lead to incorrect or misleading search results, affecting user experience and decision-making.
  • Data Loss: Corrupted or deleted data can result in permanent loss of critical information.
  • Security Risks: Compromised data may introduce vulnerabilities into applications that rely on CloudSearch for information retrieval.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider Tampering: A malicious insider with access to the CloudSearch domain intentionally modifies indexed data, leading to inaccurate search results that mislead users.
  2. External Data Injection: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the data ingestion process, injecting corrupt or malicious data into the search index, which then propagates incorrect information.
  3. CI/CD Pipeline Exploit: A flaw in the CI/CD pipeline allows unauthorized changes to the data being indexed, resulting in corrupted or incomplete search data.
